pymerkle.validations module¶

Provides a core function for validating proof and a related wrapper

class pymerkle.validations.proof_validator(validations_dir=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Wrapper of the validate_proof function.

Employs the validation_receipt class in order to organize validation results in an easy storable way.

Parameters:validations_dir (str) – [optional] absolute path of the directory where validation receipts will be stored as .json files. Defaults to None, in which case validation receipts will not be automatically stored.
validate(target_hash, proof)[source]¶

Wraps validate_proof, returning a validation receipt instead of a boolean.

If a validations_dir has been specified at construction, then the produced validation receipt is automatically stored in that directory as a .json file named with the receipt’s uuid.

Parameters:
  • target_hash (str) – hash (hexadecimal form) to be presumably attained at the end of the validation procedure (i.e., acclaimed top-hash of the Merkle-Tree having provided the proof)
  • proof (proof.proof) – the proof to be validated
Return type:

validations.validation_receipt
pymerkle.validations.validate_proof(target_hash, proof)[source]¶

Core validation function

Validates the inserted proof by comparing to the provided target hash, modifies the proof’s status as True or False according to validation result and returns this result.

Parameters:
  • target_hash (str) – hash (hexadecimal form) to be presumably attained at the end of the validation procedure (i.e., acclaimed top-hash of the Merkle-Tree having provided the proof)
  • proof (proof.proof) – the proof to be validated
Returns:

validation result
Return type:

bool
class pymerkle.validations.validationReceiptEncoder(*, skipkeys=False, ensure_ascii=True, check_circular=True, allow_nan=True, sort_keys=False, indent=None, separators=None, default=None)[source]¶

Bases: json.encoder.JSONEncoder

Used implicitely in the JSON serialization of proof receipts. Extends the built-in JSON encoder for data structures.

default(obj)[source]¶

Overrides the built-in method of JSON encoders according to the needs of this library

class pymerkle.validations.validation_receipt(proof_uuid, proof_provider, result)[source]¶

Bases: object

Encapsulates the result of proof validation

Parameters:
  • proof_uuid (str) – uuid of the validated proof (time-based)
  • proof_provider (str) – uuid of the Merkle-Tree having provided the proof
  • result (bool) – Validation result (True iff the proof was found to be valid)
Variables:
  • header – (dict) Contains the keys uuid, timestamo, validation_moment
  • header.uuid – (str) uuid of the proof (time-based)
  • header.timestamp – (str) Validation moment (msecs) from the start of time
  • header.validation_moment – (str) Validation moment in human readable form
  • body – (dict) Contains the keys proof_uuid, proof_provider, result
  • body.proof_uuid – (str) See the homonymous argument of the constructor
  • body.proof_provider – (str) See the homonymous argument of the constructor
  • body.result – (bool) See the homonymous argument of the constructor
JSONstring()[source]¶

Returns a nicely stringified version of the receipt’s JSON serialized form

Note

The output of this function is to be passed in the print() function

Return type:str
serialize()[source]¶

Returns a JSON structure with the receipt’s attributes as key-value pairs

Return type:dict
